course.name: Information Technology Operations and Project Management

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 1
lessons.content: A Tale of Two Projects is a tale of what it takes to turn around troubled projects . Jack walks into work at PintCo as a Director of Customer Relationship Management .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 2
lessons.content: Jack had only recently joined PintCo after being hired away from a chief competitor . He was still learning about some of the nuances of his current employer .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 3
lessons.content: Jack was an experienced business leader and project manager . He had seen more than his fair share of ugly project projects . Brandon asked Jack to take over the Customer Master File project from Paul .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 4
lessons.content: Jack took over the Customer Master File project, met with key project team members and conducted dozens of interviews with key stakeholders . He would be able to tell very quickly how this one would go based on the makeup of the project team .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 5
lessons.content: Brandon, a 20-year veteran at PintCo, knew what was coming . He had seen too many projects start, flounder, and then fail at the company .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 6
lessons.content: Jack's experience helped him to quickly identify a number of issues facing the project . Brandon says he's not sure how to help the project get around the world .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 7
lessons.content: Jack explains the scope of the project is not well defined and the IT architects are sitting in their ivory towers and disagree with the project's direction . “Steve from Marketing is trying to manipulate this project for his own political gain,” Jack said .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 8
lessons.content: Foundations for Success: 'If we don't change the situation this project will fail in glorious fashion' Brandon reluctantly agreed with Jack, and together they laid out several key changes .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 9
lessons.content: “We're going to end the architectural holy wars by assigning key IT architects to the project on a full time basis. No more part-time participation.” “Fourth, Brandon, you agree to be much more visible and an active participant to drive key decisions for the project”

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 10
lessons.content: Jack knew that some of these changes would be unpopular, but without them the project would be doomed . He left Brandon's office with a sense of relief and apprehension . There was still a lot of hard work and heavy lifting yet to be done .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 11
lessons.content: Brandon and Jack met in the break room as they were angling for their morning coffee refill . Brandon crowed that the Customer Master File project had been a resounding success .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 12
lessons.content: Jack says Sharon told him she was ready to quit six months ago - and now she's happier than ever and up for promotion . “I love it when a plan comes together,” Jack said proudly as he walked away and took on his next big project .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 13
lessons.content: IT organizations execute practices based on defined processes to ensure consistent service delivery . This course introduces structured IT operations through ITIL, the most commonly used system in IT management . Students will learn how to  implement IT projects in a well-organized manner .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 14
lessons.content: Successful completion of this course will enable the student to: Describe the key knowledge areas of Project Management and the project management lifecycle . Describe how projects are defined by the three key constraints of scope, schedule and cost .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 15
lessons.content: 5. y knowledge areas of Service Management and ITIL . Demonstrate the use of the Service Management process, life cycle and practices . Assess IT projects for risks and success factors . Identify and present best practices and recommendations to enhance IT projects and Service Management .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 16
lessons.content: Successful completion of the following units will enable the student to: 1.0 Managing Change 1.1 Compare Project Management and Service Management 2.0 Understanding Project Management . Apply the ethical and professional conduct of project management .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 17
lessons.content: Describe and apply the triple constraint of project management 4.0 Achieving Project Success . Present a project plan based on best practices . Describe the ethical and professional conduct of service management .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 18
lessons.content: The Four Dimensions of Service Management 7.0 explains the role of service management . Assign roles and responsibilities following service management best practices . Explain service value chain activities . Model service chain practices 9.0 Delivering General, Service and Delivering Services .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 19
lessons.content: In this document, students will be able to compare general, service and technical management practices . Present a change management plan that includes project management and service management . Use this document to help students understand the human factors of organizational change .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 27
lessons.content: RETAIN THIS DOCUMENT FOR FUTURE EDUCATIONAL\EMPLOYMENT USE Instructional Plan – MGMT8680 – S2020 School of Applied Computer Science and Information Technology Information Technology Infrastructure Program .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 28
lessons.content: Program Handbook contains many policies that affect your studies at Conestoga . IT organizations execute practices based on defined processes to ensure consistent service delivery . Projects must be planned and implemented in a well-organized manner .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 29
lessons.content: This course introduces structured IT operations through ITIL, the most commonly used system in IT management . Students learn how to manage an IT project from concept to conclusion using industry standard project management techniques .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 30
lessons.content: Project Management (PM) and Service Management (SM) are both part of organizational change management . We will introduce to the overall concept of change management in Unit 1 . Unit 2.1 – Understanding Projec will help you understand PM and SM .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 31
lessons.content: In Unit 2, you will be introduced to Project Management, it’s (2.1) key concepts, (2) ethics and professional conduct . o Describe the key concepts of project management . o When you complete this unit, you'll be able to: Describe project management roles .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 32
lessons.content: Unit 2.2 & 2.3 – Understanding Project Management . Describe the key concepts, ethics and professional conduct of project management. Describe project management roles .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 33
lessons.content: Unit 3 – Project Management Practices – In Unit 3, we will explore and discuss PM practices, including the project lifecycle, best practices, project charters and the foundational concept of The Triple Constraint .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 34
lessons.content: Unit 4 – Achieving Project Success – Discuss the key elements of project success and the best practices of project planning . Describe and apply the triple constraint of project management. elop and demonstrate the use of a project charter .

Explain roles of service management, practices, relationships and SM relationships. Assign responsibilities following best practices following service manager best practices. Explain the roles of SM, various specific practices, SM relationships o

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 38
lessons.content: Units 6.3 & 6.4 Service Management Practices will explore and discuss SM practices, such as the roles of SM, SM practices and SM relationships . Assign roles and responsibilities following service management best practices .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 39
lessons.content: Unit 7 – The Four Dimensions of Service Management Instructional Plan – MGMT8680 – S2020 . O In this unit, we will explore and discuss the four dimensions of SM – Organizations & People, Information & Technology, Partners & Suppliers, Value streams and processes .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 40
lessons.content: Unit 8 – Service Value – Explore and discuss service value chains and service chain practices . Model the four dimensions of service management and explain service value chain activities . Unit 8: Explore and explore the concept of Service Value .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 41
lessons.content: Units 9.1 & 9.2 Delivering Service Management . In Unit 9, we will discuss and explore general, service and technical management practices . When you have completed this unit, you will be able to compare and explain the difference between management practices and management practices.

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 42
lessons.content: Units 9.3 & 9.4 Delivering Service Management . In Unit 9, we will discuss and explore general, service and technical management practices . When you have completed this unit, you will be able to compare general management practices.

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 43
lessons.content: Unit 10: Managing Organizational Change . We will discuss and explore how to manage organization change . Unit 10 will focus on the integration of PM and SM practices .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 44
lessons.content: Describe and discuss the human factors of organizational change . Present a change management plan that include both project management and service management . Assigned: None .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 45
lessons.content: Final group presentations for our final assessment of the course . Self-Directed review of all course material required for final assessment . Final assessment of course will be completed by the end of the week .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 46
lessons.content: ITIL 4 in 10 minutes A quickstart guide to the latest ITSM framework . The Instructional Plan is subject to change with advance notice .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 47
lessons.content: ITIL is defined by the ITIL 4 Foundation book as: “Best-practice guidance for IT service management.” ITIL hasn't officially been referred to as the “IT Infrastructure That begs the question, What is IT Service Management? Library” since the publication of ITIL v3 in 2007 .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 48
lessons.content: ITIL 4 Glossary defines ITSM broadly as: A set of specialized organizational capabilities for enabling value for customers in the form of services . A service is defined as: “A means of enabling value co-creation by facilitating outcomes that customers want to achieve”

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 49
lessons.content: Between 2007 and 2018, ITIL v3 involved something called “the service lifecycle,” which was comprised of 26 ITSM processes and four functions . The processes were grouped across five areas: • Service strategy • Service design • Service transition • Service operation • Continual service improv .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 50
lessons.content: ITIL v3 (2011 Edition) has now been superseded by ITIL 4 and its new approach to service management . The key changes include: There’s now an ITIL service value system and service value chain .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 51
lessons.content: Understanding how ITIL 4 fits together starts with the service value . The ITIL service value system describes how all the components and system work together as a system to enable stakeholder value .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 52
lessons.content: ITIL v3 service lifecycle can be replicated in the ITIL 4 service value chain as follows: Engage – Plan – Desig .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 53
lessons.content: The ITIL service value system is “an operating model which and services” outlines the key activities required to respond to demand and facilitate . The six activities with the ITIL Service value chain are: Plan 1. n and transition – Obtain/build – Design and transition - Deliver and support – Improve .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 54
lessons.content: Design and transition–the creation of new/changed Deliver & services . Obtain/build support services that meet stakeholder expectations across quality, cost, and time to market .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 55
lessons.content: ITIL 4 Foundation book defines a management practice as “…a management practice’s’…a Quick Management Toolkit’. vice components, also ensuring that they’re available when and where needed and that agreed specifications are met.

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 56
lessons.content: ITIL is merely guidance and not an industry standard . It’s intended for organizations to take and use as needed . While the below and other ITIL 4 practices might appear new, your organization w may not be new .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 57
lessons.content: The full set of 34 ITIL 4 management practices are listed in the table on the next page . Service management practices have been adapted from technology management domains for service management purposes .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 58
lessons.content: Set of 34 ITIL 4 management practices set of 34 management practices . IT as a result of IT as well as IT as an IT as part of the ITIL set of ITIL4 management practices.

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 59
lessons.content: ITIL v3 processes are explained in ITIL 4 practices . Some of the most commonly adopted ITIL processes, now ITIL V4 practices, are explained here .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 60
lessons.content: The following table is based on ITIL v3 process adoption levels . All practice purpose descriptions are taken from the ITIL 4 Foundation book .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 61
lessons.content: Change control to maximize the number of successful changes by ensuring that risks have been properly assessed . Continual improvement to align practices and services with changing business needs . Deployment management to move new or changed hardware, software, documentation, processes, or any other component to live environments . Incident management to minimize the nega .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 62
lessons.content: Knowledge management to maintain and improve the effective, efficient, and convenient use of information and knowledge across the organization . Monitoring and event management to systematically observe services and service components as well as record and report selected changes of state identified as events . Portfolio management to ensure that the organization has the right mix of programs, projects, products, products .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 63
lessons.content: To reduce the likelihood and impact of incidents by identifying causes of incidents as well as managing workarounds and known errors . To provide a single source of consistent information on all services and service offerings and to ensure that it is available to the Service catalog management relevant audience .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 64
lessons.content: Service desk To capture demand for incident resolution and service requests . It should also be the entry point and single point of contact for users . To support the organization’s strategies and plans for service management .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 65
lessons.content: ITIL best practice has already been adopted by many organizations . ITIL aims to achieve improved IT service delivery and business operations as well as better outcomes . Service request management to support quality of a service by handling all pre-defined, user-initiated service requests .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 66
lessons.content: ServiceNow ITSM provides IT service delivery and support capabilities for tens of thousands of companies worldwide . Corporate IT organizations in pursuit of best practice IT automation look to frameworks like ITIL for guidance on improving business performance .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 67
lessons.content: ServiceNow, the ServiceNow logo, Now, Now Platform, and other ServiceNow marks are trademarks and/or registered trademarks of ServiceNow . ServiceNow is an innovative ITSM solution .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 68
lessons.content: This Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct describes the expectations that we have of ourselves and our fellow practitioners in the global project management community . It articulates the ideals to which we aspire as well as the behaviors that are manda .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 69
lessons.content: The purpose of this Code is to instill confidence in the project management profession and to help an individual become a better practitioner. We do this by establishing a profession-wide understanding of appropriate behavior. tory in our professional and volunteer roles.

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 70
lessons.content: We also believe that this Code will assist us in making wise decisions, particularly when faced with difficult situations where we may be asked to compromise our integrity or our values . We hope this Code of Ethics will serve as a catalyst for others to study, deliberate, and write about ethics and values .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 71
lessons.content: The Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct applies to: 1.2.1 All PMI members . n.2 Individuals who are not members of PMI but meet one or more of the following criteria: .1 Non-members who hold a PMI certification .2 Non-member members who serve PMI in a volunteer capacity .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 72
lessons.content: PMI also had separate ethics standards for members and for credentialed individuals . Stakeholders who contributed input to develop this Code concluded that having multiple codes was undesirable . Everyone should be held to one high standard .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 73
lessons.content: The Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct is divided into sections that contain standards of conduct which are aligned with the four values that were identified as most important to the project management community . Some sections of the Code include comments . Comments are not mandatory .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 74
lessons.content: A glossary defines words and phrases used in the Code . For convenience, those terms defined in the glossary are underlined in the text .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 75
lessons.content: The Code affirms responsibility, respect, fairness, and honesty as its foundation . The aspirational standards describe the conduct that we strive to uphold as practitioners .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 76
lessons.content: The mandatory standards establish firm requirements, and in some cases, limit or prohibit practitioner behavior . Practitioners who do not conduct themselves in accordance with these standards will be subject to disciplinary procedures before PMI’s Ethics Review Committee . The conduct covered under the aspirational standards and the mandatory standards are not mutually exclusive .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 77
lessons.content: Responsibility is our duty to take ownership for the decisions we make, the actions we take or fail to take, and the consequences that result . One specific act or omission could violate both aspirational and mandatory standards .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 78
lessons.content: We accept only those assignments that are consistent with our background, experience, skills, and qualifications . Comment: We ensure that key stakeholders receive timely and complete information regarding the gaps in our qualifications so that they may make informed decisions .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 79
lessons.content: When we discover errors or omissions caused by others, we communicate them to the appropriate body as soon they are discovered . 2.3 We fulfill commitments that we undertake – we do what we say we will do. 2.4 We take ownership and make corrections promptly .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 80
lessons.content: Project Management Professionals must uphold policies, rules, regulations and laws that govern our work, professional, a. ny resulting consequences . We must protect proprietary or confidential information that has been entrusted to us .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 81
lessons.content: We report unethical or illegal conduct to appropriate management and, if necessary, to those affected by the conduct . We do not engage in any illegal behavior, including but not limited to: theft, fraud, corruption, embezzlement, or bribery .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 82
lessons.content: As practitioners and representatives of our profession, we do not condone or assist others in engaging in illegal behavior . Since recent corporate scandals, many organizations have adopted policies to protect employees who reveal the truth about illegal or unethical activities .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 83
lessons.content: PMI only file ethics complaints when they are substantiated by facts . PMI cooperate with PMI concerning ethics violations and the collection of related information whether we are a complainant or a respondent .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 84
lessons.content: Respect is our duty to show a high regard for ourselves, others, and resources entrusted to us . We pursue disciplinary action against individuals who knowingly make false allegations against others .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 85
lessons.content: An environment of respect engenders trust, confidence, and performance excellence by fostering mutual cooperation . As practitioners in the global project management community: 3.2 Respect: Aspirational Standards .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 86
lessons.content: An implication of these provisions is that we avoid engaging in gossip and avoid making negative remarks to undermine another person’s reputation . We also have a duty under this Code to confront others who engage in these types of behaviors .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 87
lessons.content: 3.3 Respect: Mandatory Standards . We do not exercise the power of our expertise or position to influence the decisions or actions of others in order to benefit personally at their expense . We respect the property rights of others .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 88
lessons.content: 4 of 84.2 Fairness is our duty to make decisions and act impartially and objectively . Our conduct must be free from competing self interest, prejudice, and favoritism . We demonstrate transparency in our decision-making process .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 89
lessons.content: One of the biggest problems practitioners report is not recognizing when we have conflicted loyalties . We as practitioners must proactively search for potential conflicts and help each other by highlighting each other’s potential conflicts of interest .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 90
lessons.content: Situa: We make opportunities equally available to qualified candidates . We provide equal access to information to those who are authorized to have that information . We require the following of ourselves and our fellow practitioners: Conflict of Interest Situa .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 91
lessons.content: We proactively and fully disclose any real or potential conflicts of interest to the appropriate stakeholders . We refrain from engaging in the decision-making process or otherwise attempting to influence outcomes, unless or until we have made full disclosure to the affected stakeholders .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 92
lessons.content: t of interest occurs when we are in a position to influence decisions or other outcomes on behalf of one party when such decisions or outcomes could affect one or more other parties with which we have competing loyalties . For example, when acting as an employee, we have a duty of loyalty to our employer . We must recognize these divergent interests and refrain from influencing decisions .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 93
lessons.content: Even if we believe that we can set aside our divided loyalties and make decisions impartially, we treat the appearance of a conflict of interest as a conflict . We do not hire or fire, reward or punish, or award or deny contracts based on personal considerations .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 94
lessons.content: Honesty is our duty to understand the truth and act in a truthful manner . We apply the rules of the organization (employer, Project Management Institute, or other group) without favoritism or prejudice. nst others based on, but not limited to, gender, race, age, religion, disability, nationality, or sexual orientation .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 95
lessons.content: Management community: We earnestly seek the truth. We are truthful in our communications and in our conduct. We provide accurate information in a timely manner. This includes having the courage to share bad news even when it may be poorly received.

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 96
lessons.content: We make commitments and promises, implied or explicit, in good faith . When outcomes are positive, we avoid taking credit for the achievements of others . We strive to create an environment in which others feel safe to tell the truth .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 97
lessons.content: We do not engage in or condone behavior that is designed to deceive others, including but not limited to, making misleading or false statements, stating half-truths, providing information out of context or withholding information that, if known, would render our statements as misleading or incomplete . 5.3.2: We engage in dishonest behavior with the intention of personal gain or at the expense of another .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 98
lessons.content: Half-truths and non-disclosures intended to mislead stakeholders are as unprofessional as affirmatively making misrepresentations . PMI’s vision of project management as an independent profession drove our early work in ethics .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 99
lessons.content: Report was first documented PMI discussion of ethics for the project management profession . Report was submitted to the PMI Board of Directors in August 1982 . In the late 1980s, this standard evolved to become the Ethics Standard for the Project Management Professional .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 100
lessons.content: The PMI Board formed the Ethics Policy Documentation Committee to draft and publish an ethics standard for PMI’s membership . The Board approved the new Member Code of Ethics in October 1998 .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 101
lessons.content: PMI membership has grown significantly. A great deal of growth has also occurred in regions outside North America . Globalization has brought economies closer together but has caused a realization that our practice of ethics may differ from culture to culture .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 102
lessons.content: The PMI Board commissioned the Ethics Standards Review Committee [ESRC] to review the codes of ethics . The ESRC developed processes that would encourage active participation by the global project management community .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 103
lessons.content: The PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct was approved by the PMI Board of Directors in October 2006 . The first step by the Ethics Standa was the first step .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 104
lessons.content: The team analyzed the ethics codes of 24 non-profit organizations . The goal was to understand the ethical issues facing the project management community . The team developed the ethics code to try and understand the values and viewpoints of practitioners .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 105
lessons.content: ESDC developed the exposure draft of the PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct . The exposure draft was circulated to the global project management community for comment . ESDC conducted extensive research conducted by the ESDC .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 106
lessons.content: tandards Institute developed a Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct . Processes were used for 7 of 8PMI technical standard development projects and were deemed to represent the best practices for obtaining and adjudicating stakeholder feedback .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 107
lessons.content: ESDC learned that as practitioners of project management, our community takes its commitment to ethics very seriously . Violations of the PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct may result in sanctions by PMI under the ethics Case Procedures .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 108
lessons.content: Conflict of Interest is when a practitioner of project management is faced with making a decision or doing some act that will benefit the practitioner or another person or organization to which the practitioner owes a duty of loyalty and at the same time will harm another person . Conflict of interest is a decision that results in physical harm or creates intense feelings of fear, humiliation, manipulation, or exploitation in another person.

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 109
lessons.content: A person’s responsibility, legal or moral, to promote the best interest of an organization or other person with whom they are affiliated . The only way practitioners can resolve conflicting duties is to disclose the conflict .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 110
lessons.content: A person who has joined the Project Management Institute as a member . PMI-Sponsored Activities include participation on a PMI Member Advisory Group, PMI standard development team, or another PMI working group .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 111
lessons.content: Project Management Integration - Unit 3.1 – Project Management Practices • Key Concepts • In Unit 3 you will learn how to use the skills of a project, portfolio, or program, as part of project management .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 112
lessons.content: Unit 3 - Topics 1.4 Project Integration Management and Managing the Triple Constraint (3.2) Describe project integration and project best practices . Describe, develop and demonstrate the use of a project charter .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 113
lessons.content: Project Integration Management includes the processes and activities to identify, define, combine, unify, and coordinate the various processes and project management activities within the Project Management Process Group .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 114
lessons.content: Project Management Integration is a key project manager function . This is the core of project management – understanding, bringing together, directing and combining all the elements of the project . This work is typically iterative within the project and the project process groups .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 115
lessons.content: Ensuring the creation and the use of the appropriate knowledge to and from the Ensuring Project project as necessary . Managing the performance and changes of the activities in the project management Managing Integration plan . Ensuring cycle; and the benefits management plan are aligned; Ensuring cycles and benefits management plans are aligned. Ensuring due dates of the product, service, or result .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 116
lessons.content: Measuring and monitoring the project's progress and taking appropriate action to monitoring meet project objectives . Collecting data on the results achieved, analyzing the data to obtain information, Collecting and communicating this information to relevant stakeholders . Completing all the work of the project and formally closing each phase, contract, Completing and the project as a whole .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 117
lessons.content: Project Integration Management - Prof. Sean Yo MGMT-8680 11Project Integration Management . Manage Project Knowledge • Monitor and Control Project Work • Perform Integration Change Control . Perform integration change control • Perform integration Change Control • Close Project or Phase

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 118
lessons.content: The approved business case, or similar, is the business document most commonly used to develop a project . It is the document that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 119
lessons.content: IT Operations & Project Management -Prof. Sean Yo MGMT-8680 18Expert Judgement Project Data Gathering Charter Tools and Techniques Interpersonal and Team Skills Meetings .

Assigned project name and authority of manager, the sponsor or other . Project exit responsibility and person(s) authorizing authority level the project charter .

lessons.content: Project Plan Scope can be DETAILED or AIM FOR SUFFICIENCY – BE ROBUST, IT is BENEFICIAL TO HAVE BASELINE SUMMARY NOT COMPLETE PLANNING .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 122
lessons.content: IT Operations & Project Management -Prof. Sean Yo MGMT-8680 27Project Plan Outputs Project • This is the key output Management • Can include a wide range of subsidiary plans Plan • Baselines Other Outputs • Additional Components Scope Requirements Schedule management management management .

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 124
lessons.content: 7. Communications management plan 7. Cost forecasts 25. Resource calendars 8. Risk management plan 8 . Risk register 10. Risk report 11. Change management plan 11. Configuration management plan 12. Physical resource assignments 30.

lessons.title: Lesson from Section 125
